title: Virgin Galactic and Under Armour show off new spacesuits for crew, commercial passengers
text:
CLOSE

LAS CRUCES, N.M – Commercial space flight company Virgin Galactic presented the public's first look Wednesday at the spacesuits designed for its crew members, soon to include commercial passengers.

The company is ramping up to begin commercial space flights from New Mexico's Spaceport America, anticipated to start in 2020.

“Spacesuits are a part of the iconography of the first space age; our visual impressions of human spaceflight and what astronauts wear are inextricably linked," Virgin Galactic founder Richard Branson said in a statement.

The suits were jointly designed by Virgin Galactic and clothing manufacturer Under Armour, with consultation from physicians, pilots and astronaut trainers, apparel and footwear designers, engineers and ticketholders awaiting their opportunity to visit space, the spaceliner said in a statement.

The suits will be modified to fit individual astronauts, and provide cushioning at the elbows, knees and feet for safety in zero gravity conditions, Virgin Galactic said. The suits' fabric is designed to contain body temperature and manage moisture with design features compatible with the passenger cabin and seating design.

During a press tour of Virgin Galactic's New Mexico facilities in August, company representatives said seating is designed to adjust passenger's physical positions at different stages of takeoff, flight and landing.

Under Armour said its gear consists of a base layer under suits designed for comfort and practicality, including "multiple pockets for necessary and personal items including an integrated solution for communications, with a push-to-talk button." The manufacturer posted an interactive display of the gear on its website.

The unveiling of the attire in New York City comes after Virgin Galactic began moving operations from its base in Mojave, California to Spaceport America over the summer, where it has been conducting test flights in anticipation of flying its first commercial passengers in 2020.

The unveiling also took place as Virgin Galactic prepares to enter not only space, but the New York Stock Exchange, where it will sell public shares by the end of the year. The company announced a merger with Social Capital Hedosophia this summer, a capital firm owned by venture capitalist Chamath Palihapitiya. The merger is valued at $1.5 billion.
